p: Phenolic acids have been recently widely studied because of their potential protective roles. Phenolic acids have a benzene ring, a carboxylic group, and one or more hydroxyl and/or methoxyl groups. They are usually divided into benzoic acid derivatives (i.e., hydroxybenzoic acids, C 6-C 1) ( Figure 1a) and cinnamic acid derivatives (i.e., hydroxycinnamic acids, C 6-C 3) ( Figure 1b), based on the constitutive carbon structures. The amount of hydroxybenzoic acid (C 6-C 1 derivatives) (e.g., gallic acid, salicylic acid, salicylaldehyde, and protocatechuic acid) is typically low in edible plants [ 14]. Phenolic acids may make up about one-third of the phenolic compounds in the human diet; these substances have a powerful antioxidant activity that may help protect the body from free radicals [ 9, 15].
